newsitem.title: ZAMBIA: Zambia sells mine stake to Cyprus Amax.
newsitem.headline: Zambia sells mine stake to Cyprus Amax.

text.p: Zambia kicked off the sale of its biggest state-owned company Thursday by agreeing to sell an 80 percent stake in a copper mine to Colorado-based Cyprus Amax Minerals Co.
The purchase price was not disclosed.
As part of the deal, Cyprus will acquire the mineral base at the Kansanshi mine, said Zambia Consolidated Copper Mines Ltd. (ZCCM), the state-owned company that owns the mine.
Englewood, Colo.-based Cyprus is one the biggest copper producers in the United States, and also mines coal, gold and molybdenum, which is used in alloys and making spark plug points.

Kansanshi is the first ZCCM mine to be sold under Zambia's ambitious programme to sell off state assets, under which about 130 state-owned firms have been sold over four years. Economists have called the plan Africa's most successful privatisation programme.

The sale of ZCCM, which generates about 90 percent of the country's foreign exchange earnings, is seen as crucial to help Zambia's mining industry. Falling copper prices have hurt Zambia, formerly one of the world's largest producers.
ZCCM Chairman Luke Mwananshiku said the company's financial problems meant it needed to sell its mines, smelters and other assets soon. The assets have been split into packages for the sale.
Industry analysts said ZCCM earnings fell 33 percent last year from 1995.
